reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s overall case: the second-half taxonomy-based inference that “only a narrow slice of plausible views are easygoing,” which is used to support the headline “no easy eutopia” conclusion. If that generalization were undermined, a major argumentative route to the conclusion weakens, though the essay also has independent motivation from ‘fragility’/multiplicative-factor considerations—so centrality is substantial but not total. The critique’s strength is moderate: it plausibly notes that the paper’s classification scheme is coarse and may omit hybrid/pluralist/non-welfarist moral architectures, but it mostly gestures rather than demonstrating that these omitted views are (i) plausible under the essay’s own VNM/cardinal framing, and (ii) genuinely “easygoing” rather than merely differently fussy (e.g., threshold views can be extremely sensitive near constraints). Most statements are broadly correct (taxonomy coarseness; many moral theories exist; generalization is contestable), though the claim that these frameworks “potentially” make the target large is speculative and under-argued. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little filler.
title: The taxonomic dichotomy may overlook nuanced moral views
